message: I like how vim (not gui) you can hit control-z and fg to jump back and forth from vim to terminal, is this possible with mvim?
I like to keep a single window open that has both my editor and a prompt to run my tests
That's a terminal feature, not vim's. I think the closest you can get is issuing commands from mvim with ":!yourcommand".

I typically run vim within a byobu (screen) session so I can just F3/F4 between windows. Not the same as what you're asking but it works great. I also sometimes use ConqueTerm when I want to run bash or iPython from within vim (works great for writing docs, building up shell scripts, etc.)
What does ":!sh" do for you? I get (in Ubuntu) a shell inside my gvim session

I second @unbracketed's ConqueTerm suggestion for running within MacVim, it's swell. And similar to his screen suggestion, I use tmux and on Mac you can use an alias like `alias vim='/Applications/MacVim.app/Contents/MacOS/Vim' to invoke your more featureful MacVim build (Python and Ruby plugin support, etc.) in the console. For icing on the cake, use iTerm for 256-color terminal support and check out CSApprox for your color schemes.

FWIW, my setup is to use Visor (http://visor.binaryage.com/) so the terminal is always a ctrl-` away.  Also, if you're using MacVim from homebrew you might find this alias useful: https://gist.github.com/910470

@tvon I was a Visor addict too -- the latest iTerm has a Visor-style function that has finally made me a convert (plus other awesome features): https://groups.google.com/d/msg/iterm2-discuss/2Gofll9f5YY/UV3MG0W32iMJ

It's not quite as slick, but if you are just bouncing between your MacVim window and your (i)term window, you can just hit Command-Tab to go back and forth between the windows.  It'll take a couple more hits if you've gone to another application in the meanwhile.

I use Quicksilver and assigned triggers to launch Terminal and MacVim. When these apps are already opened, pressing the shortcut will focus on the corresponding window. (e.g. Ctrl-Cmd-t to open Terminal or switch to it if already opened)
@ches thanks for the tip. Visor user here too - will give iTerm2 a look
@ches If the point is to use the version of Vim that comes with MacVim, then if you are using homebrew you can do this automatically: brew install macvim --override-system-vim /cc @tvon
@charlietanksley Thanks, I'll have a look at the macvim Homebrew formula.
@ches I was having a problem getting my system to always use the right Vim when I found that option. It really simplified things for me. Hope it helps.
